predicate.note: Frames file for 'strip' based on sentences in wsj. Verbnet entries 10.4.1 and 10.6, Framenet entries Emptying and Removing.

example.name: source as direct object
example.text: The 1990 appropriations legislation attempts *trace* to strip the president of his powers to make certain appointments as provided by Article II.
example.arg: his powers to make certain appointments as provided by Article II

example.name: removed substance as DO
example.text: When an agreement was reached *trace* to strip capital gains from the legislation, Oregon Sen. Bob Packwood, the ranking GOP member of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, hailed it.

example.name: passivized substance
example.text: But they were stripped *trace* from the Senate bill after staffers estimated penalty revenue would fall by $216 million over five years.
example.arg: after staffers estimated penalty revenue would fall by $216 million over five years

example.name: no source mentioned
example.text: And on back-to-back roll calls, 206-199 and 223-178, the Appropriations Committee leadership turned back efforts *trace* to weaken or strip the proposed restrictions first added by Sen. Warren Rudman (R., N.H.).

example.name: missing substance defaults to 'clothes'
example.text: The games Bronx children played (holding kids down and stripping them, for example) seem tame by today's crack standards, but Ms. Cunningham makes it all sound like a great adventure.

example.name: intransitive is the fun case!
example.text: John stripped in front of Mary's dinner guests.
example.arg: in front of Mary's dinner guests

example.name: active
example.text: Applying prowess gained during earlier stints at appliance maker AB Electrolux, Mr. Andersson and a handful of loyal lieutenants aggressively stripped away dead wood -- and got quick results.
example.arg: Mr. Andersson and a handful of loyal lieutenants

example.name: passive
example.text: The insurance brokerage agency, just a fragment of Helmsley's vast empire, would be the first piece of the company *trace* *trace* to be stripped *trace* away since last summer when Mr. Helmsley's wife, Leona Helmsley, was found guilty of tax evasion.
